#Text=1 .
#Text=Introduction
#Text=The electromagnetic ( EM ) assisted enhanced oil recovery ( EOR ) method has gained significant attention for the recovery of residual oil .
#Text=The transfer of EM energy to reservoir materials depends on the molecular composition , such as the dipolar and magnetic molecules having free or bound charges like electrons or ions .
#Text=Therefore , EM waves behave differently at different interfaces within the reservoir .
#Text=The propagating EM wave exerts forces on the molecules , which then align in a direction parallel to the external EM field .
#Text=Application of electromagnetic ( EM ) waves of certain frequency ranges has been used in nanofluid core flooding experiments for stimulating the recovery of residual oil after water flooding .
#Text=The potential efficiency of this method has been demonstrated by several experimental and numerical studies .
#Text=Different recovery mechanisms other than the common EM heating method have been reported recently .
#Text=For instance , the application of a magnetic field gradient for the polarization of ferromagnetic nanofluid during nanoflooding experiments has been demonstrated .

#Text=A considerable recovery factor attributed to interfacial tension ( IFT ) reduction and hyperthermia phenomena has also been reported with the application of EM waves ( frequency range 500 â€“ 1000 MHz ) .
#Text=There have also been similar reports on the use of EM waves for wettability alteration , implying an improvement in reservoir oil production rate .
#Text=Currently , few research articles have been generated on transmitter design considerations for EM-assisted oil recovery processes .

#Text=For instance , numerical studies on EM-assisted oil recovery using a shaped dipole antenna was conducted by , likewise , a cylindrical antenna model using the wavelets analysis method has also been reported .
#Text=Similarly , dimensional constraints have been considered in simulating three types of antennae at different operating frequencies , 915 MHz , 2.45 GHz and 5.8 GHz .

#Text=Despite the amount of reported studies , the effect of reservoir EM properties at varying formation fluid contents on the efficiency of the EM transmitter , and its propagation pattern have not been considered .

#Text=Most of the reported studies irradiate the reservoir with EM waves of an arbitrary frequency ( sometimes based on dimensional constraints ) without considering the medium â€™s EM response , and its effect on the antenna operating frequency .
#Text=Thus , this area requires further investigation .
#Text=This is crucial because the operating frequency , penetration depth and radiation pattern of a transmitter depend on reservoir EM properties .

#Text=These properties include the electrical conductivity Ïƒ , dielectric permittivity Îµ and magnetic permeability Âµ , all of which vary with fluid content , and are frequency dependent in varying degrees .

#Text=Consequently , it is vital to factor reservoir EM properties into the determination of antenna dimensions and operating frequency to achieve the desired uniform far-field pattern , homogenous EM energy dissipation and to avoid hot spots on the antenna surface .

#Text=Furthermore , the three-dimensional far-field pattern of a plane wave can be obtained from Equation ( 1 ) , expressed in terms of the complex permittivity , permeability and conductivity of the medium .

#Text=( 1 ) where Î¼r is the relative permeability , E is the electric field vector , k 0 is the wavenumber in free space , Îµr is the relative permittivity , Ï‰ is the angular frequency , Ïƒ is conductivity and Îµ0 is the permittivity of free space .

#Text=Thus , the phasor is represented as , where r is the propagation distance , Î³ ( mâˆ’1 ) is the propagation constant , which is a complex quantity of the form , where the real part Î± ( Np/m ) is the attenuation factor and the imaginary part Î² ( rad/m ) is the phase constant .
#Text=Generally , oil reservoirs are a low-loss medium , that is .
#Text=Hence , the irradiated EM waves are absorbed and attenuated as they propagate and spread within the medium .
#Text=Therefore , the attenuation factor Î± and phase constant Î² becomes : ( 2 ) ( 3 )

#Text=The skin depth/penetration depth Î´ in low-loss media is , which is the inverse of the attenuation constant indicating the distance travelled by the wave in the medium before its amplitude reduces to 1/e of its initial value on the surface of the transmitter .
#Text=The half-wave dipole antenna was used in this study due to its extensive application in the EM enhanced oil recovery method , because of its radiation pattern .
#Text=This type of transmitter focuses the EM energy in the center of the dipole and exhibits an omnidirectional radiation pattern .
#Text=The relationship between the length of a half-wave dipole and its operating wavelength has been established by .
#Text=The conventional method is to design an antenna with a calculated length based on a predetermined frequency of propagation .
#Text=However , considering the constraint and practical feasibility of transmitter placement in a reservoir well , it is reasonable to fix the antenna dimension based on reservoir geometry .
#Text=Thereafter calculating its operating frequency over a range of possible values of reservoir EM properties ( Îµ , Î¼ and Ïƒ ) for optimal EM radiation .
#Text=Hence , this research investigates the impact of reservoir effective EM properties at different fluid saturations on the operating efficiency of a half-wave dipole antenna .
#Text=The ensuing EM propagation pattern of the antenna in a cylindrical oil reservoir model and its operating frequencies were analyzed .
